Organsiationen The Students and Youth Working on reproductive Health Action Team (SAYWHAT) är en civilsamhällsorganisation (registered under Private and Voluntary Organisation Act PVO 34/2017) som arbetat sedan 2003 med SRHR för unga framförallt inom universiteten i Zimbabwe.
SAYWHAT arbetar dynamiskt och innovativt med unga för att stärka unga kvinnors sexuella rättigheter samt att påverka myndighter och regierigen. Organisationen arbetar även med att påverka SADC (the Southern African Development Committee) och AU (the Africa Union) runt SRHR policy arbete.
Främsta målgruppen för Sveriges nya strategin är ungdomar. Denna målgrupp är särskilt relevant då en av tre unga flickor i Zimbabwe utsätts för sexuella övergrepp innan de fyllt 16 år. Zimbabwe har även några av de högsta siffrorna vad gäller barnäktenskap och könsrelaterat våld i södra Afrika (mer information i Global Gender Gap Report och i Girls Not Brides Report). SAYWHAT programmet inkluderar ett rättighetsperspektiv och fattiga människors perspektiv på utveckling, och har ett särskilt fokus på utsatta ungdomar.
Ambassaden bedömer denna insats som mycket intressant och relevant för vår strategi särskilt vad gäller område 1.3 Stärkta förutsättningar för jämställdhet och respekt för mänskliga rättigheter, med fokus på kvinnor och flickor; samt 2.2 Ökad tillgång till och respekt för sexuell och reproduktiv hälsa och rättigheter, framförallt för unga människor. Ett stöd till SAY WHAT innebär att vi kan minska antalet oönskade graviditeter och öka tillgången till preventivmedel bland unga kvinnor i Zimbabwe. Genom denna insats kommer Sverige att bidra till att fler ungdomar kan fatta välgrundade beslut om sin hälsa, sexualitet och reproduktion. Stödet till SAYWHAT kommer även att komplettera stöde till Marie Stopes (PSZ) och Population Serviec International som arbetar med tillhandahavandet av preventivmedel.

The Students and Youth Working on reproductive Health Action Team (SAYWHAT) is registered under the Private and Voluntary Organisation Act (PVO 34/2017). The organisation was formed in 2003 to provide a conducive platform to deliberate on students unmet Sexual and Reproductive Health need. The platform is also a mechanism through which students and youths coordinate themselves to inform Sexual and Reproductive Health and public health policies, programs and practise. Over the years, SAYWHAT has proved to be a dynamic and innovative space, attracting recognition and partnerships from college authorities, the government of Zimbabwe, international and national funding and implementing partners, the Southern African Development Committee, and the Africa Union on matters relating to Sexual and Reproductive Health Rights of students.
Background of the contribution
According to the 2012 Census, about 60% of Zimbabweans are below the age of 24 and this scenario presents socio-economic challenges ranging from inadequacies in health service provision, quality education and unemployment amongst other development facet priorities for young people. The Ministry of Health and Child Care in 2010 launched an Adolescent Sexual and Reproductive Health Strategy which sought to operationalize provisions of the Reproductive Health Policy regarding young people’s access to comprehensive sexuality education and related services in a Youth Friendly manner. The Strategy was intended to be co-implemented with the Ministries of Youth, Primary and Secondary Education, Higher and Tertiary Education. Sub-sequent reviews in 2013 and 2016 showed that the Ministries have not fully implemented the ASRH Strategy, thus intended benefits have not accrued to young people in schools (Ministry of Primary and Secondary Education), young people out of schools (Ministry of Youth) and young people in Higher Education (Ministry of Higher and Tertiary Education).
The Ministry of Health has rolled out the Sex and Sexuality Life Skills Strategy but most health indicators remain negative for young people with their HIV Prevalence standing at 10% in the 15 – 24-year age group. The Zimbabwe Demographic Health Survey 2015/16 has showed a general decline of HIV Incidence, mortality and morbidity in the reproductive age of 15 – 45 years. However, such has not been enjoyed by young people who still have more than 50% of the new infections, high rates of poor adherence to ART and a higher HIV Mortality rate. The Adolescent Fertility Study of 2016 showed that the Unmet Contraception need for adolescents is at 12,8% and the Contraception Prevalence rate in the same age group is at 10%. The current fertility rate amongst adolescents and young people 15 – 24 is 27% in rural areas and 10% in urban areas. Child bearing has a significant impact on young people’s access to quality education, and exposes them to other vulnerabilities such as STIs and Cervical Cancer. Zimbabwe has further recorded high levels of child arriages with rural areas recording 27% and urban areas 16% of adolescent girls and young women 15 – 19 years. Such has also significantly contributed to maternal mortality.
Adolescents (15 – 19) constitute 24% of the total maternal mortality deaths. Zimbabwe has not publicised any population based surveys on the effects of unsafe abortions but there has been reference to an average of between 70 000 to 90 000 abortions per annum. Zimbabwe has one of the highest incidences of physical and sexual abuse of women and girls. According to the National Baseline Survey on Life Experiences of Adolescents (NBSLEA 2011), about 33,4% of young women aged 18 – 24 years have experienced physical and sexual violence before reaching the age of 18. Population based surveys have further revealed that women, young people adolescent girls and young women are disproportionately affected by Sexual and Reproductive Health infirmities.
The impact of the SRH challenges is worsened by structural and underlying political, socio-cultural and economic factors. Sexuality Education for young people has not been mainstreamed and standardized in the education system. Young people continue to rely on informal sources of information which are sometimes inaccurate, age-inappropriate or not scientifically proven. Decisions for non-contraception use by adolescent girls and young women are further buttressed by powerful institutions that govern young people’s sexuality such as patriarchy, religion and cultural practises. Furthermore, some young people are faced with attitudinal and perception barriers of health service providers. Description of the contribution
Following the above stated challenges, SAYWHAT proposes a three year, SEK16 000 000 Action for Choice (A4C) project. The A4C project is inspired by a belief in students’ power to make choices about their Sexual and Reproductive Health. It is built on an understanding that if students’ Sexual and Reproductive Health choices are broadened, there is increased potential for them to excel in other development facets such as education, professional careers and employability. The project aims to improve access to and utilisation of contraception, HIV and GBV services by students in 10 State Universities in Zimbabwe. It seeks to achieve this through harnessing the collective action of students, and strengthening their voices to make choices on SRH services that have an impact on their lives. It seeks to ensure that duty bearers craft policies and programs which are in line with students preferred choices with reference to choices that have been taken away from them on morality, religious and cultural grounds.
Noting the high numbers of sexual abuse, SAYWHAT will ensure and facillitate that all universities and tertiary institutions have a Sexual Abuse and Sexual Exploitation (SASE) policy that protects that students (from fellow students and institution staff members) and details the reporting mechanisms and whistleblowing protocols.
The Action for Choice Project shall primarily target as ultimate beneficiary’s students from the 10 State Universities. The project shall not be selective in excluding students and/or young people to be key beneficiaries of the project however, special attention shall be given to students with disabilities, students living with HIV, first year students, students on internship, and student survivors of Gender Based Violence.

description.narrative: Through Resource Centres (that were established and strengthened within the Action for Choice implementing universities in 2019), the project continued to link students with critical Sexual Reproductive Health service providers. In 2020, Resource Centres became common facilities frequented by students to access SRHR information and referral for services. Although Resource Centres had to be closed end of March due to lockdown and subsequent closure of schools, more than 5 000 students had already accessed information and referrals through the Resource Centres. SAYWHAT strengthened its WhatsApp and social media platforms to continue the engagements with young people to try and fill the information gap created by the closure of resource centres. SAYWHAT needs to introduce a mandatory online induction programme especially for first year students and push for the incorporation of the same in the college induction package. This will ensure SAYWHAT is able to reach the students with vital SRHR information and assess the information gaps despite disturbances caused by emergencies like Covid-19. With support from the Embassy SAYWHAT introduced SRHR law clinics to improve interaction and accessibility of legal services and advise to students in tertiary institutions. The SRHR Law clinic was a platform to stimulate conversations using direct interface with Legal Practitioners. The SRHR Law Clinic exposed the existing knowledge gaps among students on legal matters related to their SRHR. Moving forward Saywhat needs to have webinars or virtual conferences for these law clinics addressing different modules to broaden the reach both in geographic reach and in numbers. With the advent of Covid-19 and the subsequent restrictions SAYWHAT with support from the Embassy manage to adapt to virtual programming initiatives that enabled the continued availability by students and young people to accurate Sexuality Information Education. The National Universities’ Quiz and Debate Competitions, the Virtual National Students Conference and Co-creation support initiatives such as the CONDOMIZE! Campaigns and Orange Day Commemorations, SAYWHAT reached out and impacted the lives of over 520, 000 young people in a space of 6 months. The Covid-19 related movement restrictions however resulted in significant decrease in general access to and increased violations of SRHR. Existing vulnerabilities among young women were exacerbated as their access to services was curtailed away from tertiary institutions along with the support that comes with it. Although the online activities have a wider reach the activities have its myriad of challenges stemming from mobilisation and digital poverty among the most vulnerable young people. When the tertiary schools shifted from physical to online learning, SRHR information fell by the wayside and was not included in learning packages. And even where it is, with connectivity still being a luxury rather than a right and an ever-widening digital gender gap, girls and young women from marginalised, poorer households are the least likely to be able to access this information. There is need for SAYWHAT to find innovative ways to bridge this widening digital divide. This includes developing more partnerships with community-based radios to reach the marginalised young people. SAYWHAT also needs to work on strengthening and rolling out of online modules on SRHR that can be infused in the mainstream learning. SAYWHAT with its strong influence on young people acted as a conduit of Covid-19 information. Covid-19 awareness and support were mainstreamed and ensuring that young people were given up to date information on the pandemic through the Smart Choice Mobile Application, Meet the Expert sessions, Online Competitions, Webinars and Online Infomercials on SAYWHAT Social Media Platforms. The project also facilitated the student’s interaction with policy makers in shaping the COVID-19 discourse at National level. However, the Government in most cases continued with the tokenism approach to young people’s participation where it made unilateral decisions affecting the young people To strengthen real time dissemination of Sexuality Information and Education and linkages to services SAYWHAT launched a Call for Choice Toll Free Line facility /Call Centre in 2020. The facility has successfully closed the information and service linkage gap for young people in Zimbabwe and neighbouring countries like Mozambique and Zambia. Besides handling Sexual Reproductive Health issues for young people, the Call for Choice Toll Free facility managed a significant number of cases related to Child Protection and this has helped SAYWHAT to strengthen its Child Protection programming initiatives. There is however need to strengthen the referral pathway and follow up to ensure the young people who come through the toll free access the services they need. The installation of Solar Systems in 3 SAYWHAT Provincial Satellite Offices through the support from the Swedish Embassy in Zimbabwe has improved operational and administrative efficiency of these satellite offices and will and ensure uninterrupted internet connectivity for both students and staff in those tertiary institutions. More so, the procurement and setting up of Video Conferencing equipment enabled SAYWHAT to host its first Virtual National Students Conference and will go a long way in improving SAYWHAT virtual programming given the new normal. The Embassy will have dialogue with SAYWHAT to ensure the studio is used efficiently for the benefit of the broader SRHR agenda.
